CARDINAL . The relevant part of the Appendix to Committee of Ministers Recommendation Rec(CARDINAL)CARDINAL reads as follows :

CARDINAL . When a judgment which points to structural or general deficiencies in national law or practice ( ' pilot case ' ) has been delivered and a large number of applications to the ORG concerning the same problem ( ' repetitive cases ' ) are pending or likely to be lodged , the respondent state should ensure that potential applicants have , where appropriate , an effective remedy allowing them to apply to a competent national authority , which may also apply to current applicants . Such a rapid and effective remedy would enable them to obtain redress at national level , in line with the principle of subsidiarity of the Convention system .

CARDINAL . The introduction of such a domestic remedy could also significantly reduce the ORG 's workload . While prompt execution of the pilot judgment remains essential for solving the structural problem and thus for preventing future applications on the same matter , there may exist a category of people who have already been affected by this problem prior to its resolution . The existence of a remedy aimed at providing redress at national level for this category of people might allow the ORG to invite them to have recourse to the new remedy and , if appropriate , declare their applications inadmissible .

CARDINAL . Several options with this objective are possible , depending , among other things , on the nature of the structural problem in question and on whether the person affected by this problem has applied to the ORG or not .

CARDINAL . In particular , further to a pilot judgment in which a specific structural problem has been found , CARDINAL alternative might be to adopt an ad hoc approach , whereby the state concerned would assess the appropriateness of introducing a specific remedy or widening an existing remedy by legislation or by judicial interpretation .

CARDINAL . Within the framework of this case - by - case examination , states might envisage , if this is deemed advisable , the possibility of reopening proceedings similar to those of a pilot case which has established a violation of the Convention , with a view to saving the ORG from dealing with these cases and where appropriate to providing speedier redress for the person concerned . The criteria laid out in Recommendation Rec(CARDINAL)CARDINAL of ORG might serve as a source of inspiration in this regard .

CARDINAL . When specific remedies are set up following a pilot case , governments should speedily inform the ORG so that it can take them into account in its treatment of subsequent repetitive cases .

CARDINAL . However , it would not be necessary or appropriate to create new remedies , or give existing remedies a certain retroactive effect , following every case in which a ORG judgment has identified a structural problem . In certain circumstances , it may be preferable to leave the cases to the examination of the ORG , particularly to avoid compelling the applicant to bear the further burden of having once again to exhaust domestic remedies , which , moreover , would not be in place until the adoption of legislative changes .

CARDINAL . In DATE following the Second World War the communist regimes in numerous central and eastern NORP countries conducted massive programmes of nationalisation and expropriation of immovable property , industrial , banking and commercial structures and , with the exception of GPE , agricultural structures .

CARDINAL . In DATE restitution measures were adopted in many of these countries , whose political and legal situations differed . The detailed arrangements and scope of the measures varied and there were wide differences in the forms of compensation adopted by States .
CARDINAL . GPE , GPE and GPE and GPE ) have not enacted any legislation concerning restitution or compensation in respect of properties that were nationalised or confiscated .

CARDINAL . The legislation in GPE does not establish a general right to restitution or compensation in respect of properties that were confiscated or nationalised . The sole exception concerns the LOC region and is confined to a right to compensation . In practice , the persons entitled can opt either to have the index - linked value of the abandoned properties deducted from the price of a ORG - owned property acquired by means of a competitive bidding procedure , or to receive money from the compensation fund . The amount of compensation which claimants may receive is subject to a statutory ceiling of PERCENT of the current value of the property lost in LOC .

CARDINAL . NORP The NORP legislation on partial compensation for damage caused to citizens ' property by the ORG provides for compensation to be paid in monetary form or in the form of coupons . There is also a statutory cap on compensation .

CARDINAL . NORP The majority of the countries concerned restrict the right to restitution or compensation to certain categories of properties or claimants . In some countries the legislation lays down time - limits , sometimes very short , for lodging claims .

CARDINAL . NORP Some countries provide for various forms of restitution and/or compensation by means of so - called “ restitution ” laws : this is the case in GPE , GPE , GPE and “ the former GPE ” . Others have dealt with the issue of restitution under rehabilitation laws ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) . Finally , the issue is also dealt with under property legislation ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) .
CARDINAL . NORP In all cases , restitution is not an absolute right and may be subject to numerous conditions and restrictions . The same is true of the right to compensation .

CARDINAL . Either the former owners or their successors in title ( lawful heirs in GPE ) may be eligible for restitution or compensation in respect of confiscated or nationalised property . In some countries including GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE , the legislation requires the claimant to be a citizen either when the property was confiscated or when the claim for restitution is made , or in some cases even both . In addition , the law in GPE and GPE requires claimants to be permanent residents both when the law entered into force and when the claim for restitution or compensation is made . In those systems where there is a rehabilitation procedure , only persons rehabilitated in accordance with the law may claim restitution of their property . This is the case in GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE . In these countries entitlement to restitution or compensation is wholly or partially linked to the rehabilitation of victims of political repression .
CARDINAL . The legislation in some countries excludes several categories of properties from restitution or compensation .

CARDINAL . In some cases the legislation excludes land and buildings the character of which has been altered ( GPE ) ; other countries exclude property which has lost its original character ( GPE ) or property which has disappeared or been destroyed , as well as properties which have passed into private ownership ( GPE , GPE and GPE ) .

CARDINAL . In addition , under NORP law , military property , cultural and social assets and property under ORG protection , as well as buildings used by the ORG or local administrative authorities , are excluded from restitution . Under the legislation in GPE plots of land , forests , perennial plantations and property confiscated on grounds unrelated to political repression are also ineligible for restitution .
CARDINAL . In GPE and GPE properties which were nationalised in accordance with the legislation in force at the time do not qualify for restitution or compensation .

CARDINAL . In GPE restitution is possible only in the case of residential property . The NORP legislation provides only for partial restitution of agricultural land . Finally , in GPE and GPE the restitution laws specify the properties which are covered .

CARDINAL . Some legislation imposes temporal restrictions on the lodging of claims for restitution or compensation . This is the case in GPE and GPE , where former owners were given DATE in which to lodge a claim , and in GPE , GPE and “ the former GPE ” ( DATE from the date of entry into force of the law on rehabilitation ) .

CARDINAL . Elsewhere , the legislation restricts restitution or compensation to properties nationalised or confiscated during a certain period . By way of example , the NORP compensation scheme is limited to properties nationalised after DATE but compensation is awarded for properties nationalised DATE in the NORP - occupied zone .

CARDINAL . A number of countries have opted to provide compensation in the form of another property equivalent to that which was nationalised or confiscated ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and “ the former GPE ” ) .

CARDINAL . Where no exchange is possible the legislation allows the person concerned to be provided with a property of a different kind , a sum of money , compensation vouchers ( GPE and GPE ) , ORG securities or bonds ( GPE and “ the former GPE ” ) or shares in a public company ( GPE and GPE ) .

CARDINAL . The amount of compensation is calculated mainly by reference to the market value of the property at the time of the restitution or compensation decision ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) or at the time the property was confiscated ( “ the former GPE ” ) , or as otherwise provided by law .

ORG . NORP Some countries take account of other considerations in addition to the market price . In GPE , when compensation is provided in the form of shares the amount is equal to the value of the property at the time of the decision or the value of the privatised public property .

CARDINAL . Other factors may also be taken into consideration in determining the amount of compensation . In GPE , for instance , account is taken of the value of the property before expropriation , which is then multiplied by a coefficient laid down by law .
CARDINAL . In some countries the legislation sets a cap on compensation ( GPE , GPE and GPE ) , or provides for payment in instalments ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . The authorities responsible for determining restitution or compensation claims may be judicial or administrative . The most common arrangements include special restitution and compensation boards ( GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) , administrative bodies ( GPE ) , ORG or ORG , or even the courts ( GPE ) . In all the countries surveyed an appeal lies to the administrative or civil courts against the decisions of the administrative bodies .
